awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Time-Resolved Mossbauer Spectroscopy, a New Tool for Investigating Ultrafast Dynamics in Solid-State Photocatalytic and Photovoltaic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description
Improving the function of solar harvesting devices made from cheap, durable materials is necessary to make solar technology an integral part of a clean, renewable energy strategy. The efficiency of a photovoltaic or photocatalytic device is generally determined by events that occur within the first few picoseconds to nanoseconds following absorption of light, and thus a thorough understanding of electronic and chemical dynamics on this ultrafast timescale is crucial for guiding the design of next-generation materials. Transient absorption spectroscopy has long been deployed to this end, wherein an ultrashort laser pump pulse synchronously launches processes in a sample and a probe pulse reports on the state of the system at a later time. But while this approach has proven enormously successful in providing molecular movies of reactions in solution, laser-induced heating inevitably gives rise to spurious signals in solid-state materials. This project aims to solve that dilemma by pioneering an entirely new ultrafast X-ray technique that probes atomic nuclei instead of electrons. Because this technique requires the exceptionally bright X-ray pulses provided by large-scale storage ring light sources, this work will be performed at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory. A residency at this world-class facility will provide the University of Rhode Island research team the unique opportunity to demonstrate TRSRM for the first time and track the formation of short-lived chemical species in several solid-state solar energy conversion materials.

Technical Description 
Recent work in ultrafast optical and X-ray transient absorption spectroscopy has highlighted the deficiencies of these traditional approaches for studying photochemical dynamics in the solid-state due to the presence of massive thermal artifacts that arise from laser-induced heating. This project aims to develop and demonstrate time-resolved synchrotron radiation M?ssbauer spectroscopy (TRSRM), a novel and difficult X-ray technique that will provide an unambiguous probe of excited state dynamics in a wide variety of solid-state photocatalytic and photovoltaic materials, including hematite, iron titanate, and organolead halide perovskites. M?ssbauer spectroscopy retains  element specificity and oxidation/spin state sensitivity of X-ray techniques while boasting exceptionally narrow linewidths, straightforward assignments, and most importantly for ultrafast implementation of the technique a relative insensitivity to large thermal variations. TRSRM may also be performed under electrochemical working conditions, an absolute requirement for investigating the function of photoelectrochemical materials such as hematite. By providing clear mechanistic insight into how these materials function, this work will pave the way for critical assessments (and reassessments) of the chemical and physical properties that enhance or diminish performance in many photoactive materials and guide the efforts of materials engineers to improve solar energy conversion efficiency through rational design. Because TRSRM can only be performed at a time-resolved hard X-ray spectroscopy beamline, the research team will travel to the Advanced Photon Source to prepare and execute the initial experiments. Following successful demonstration of picosecond-resolved TRSRM, the team will seek to identify not only transient species but also transition states in solid-state materials through femtosecond-resolved TRSRM at hard X-ray free electron laser facilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall aim of this project was to develop a new method for observing ultrafast processes in solid-state photovoltaic and photocatalytic materials for solar energy conversion by probing atomic nuclei with X-rays following excitation with laser pulses, which we dubbed ?time-resolved synchrotron radiation M?ssbauer spectroscopy,? or TRSRM. This method is urgently needed, as existing techniques often cannot unequivocally distinguish between the electronic effects responsible for the performance of the material(s) under investigation and laser-induced heating. Our collaborative efforts with X-ray beamline staff at Argonne National Laboratory have been delayed due to the pandemic, though we will be resuming this work in 2022. In the meantime, however, we have shifted our focus to studying light-induced chemical reactions using lab-based techniques including ultrafast optical transient absorption spectroscopy and radioisotope M?ssbauer spectroscopy.

We have used a combination of time-resolved X-ray and optical spectroscopies to study a class of organic reactions called photocycloadditions that may be driven by light with the aid of copper ions to fuse two molecules together. These reactions are crucial to the synthesis of several molecules of pharmaceutical and biological importance and may also be used to store solar energy in carbon-carbon chemical bonds. But despite such important applications, the mechanisms of these reactions ? that is, the pathways by which electrons rearrange following the absorption of light to drive the formation of bonds ? have remained unknown since they were first discovered in the mid-20th century. We have found that the reaction proceeds by entirely different mechanisms for two remarkably similar reactants, and we are now using this insight to broaden the scope of molecules that may be combined in this manner. This reaction takes advantage of the incredible amount of energy in a single photon to drive a transformation that otherwise would require multiple challenging (or often impossible) synthetic steps, and we expect our work will lead to cheaper and more environmentally friendly means of preparing a variety of drugs and industrial chemicals.

We have also used a similar approach to study the behavior of the ferrate(VI) ion in water following ultraviolet excitation. Potassium ferrate is a promising material for water treatment in rural communities, as it is capable of eliminating a broad range of organic contaminants in water with minimal additional infrastructure while producing only non-toxic byproducts, but its potency under ultraviolet irradiation is limited by competing pathways that dissipate the potential photochemical energy as waste heat. Our results have allowed us to quantify and trace these pathways, and we are now working toward directly observing the interaction of photoexcited ferrate ions with organic contaminants in municipal water samples.

In a parallel effort, we have used radioisotope M?ssbauer spectroscopy and nuclear resonance inelastic X-ray scattering to characterize the vibrational modes of tin halide perovskites, a class of next-generation photovoltaic materials that exhibit excellent solar energy conversion efficiency but very poor long-term stability. Much of this instability arises from the ease with which ions can move within the lattice, and while two-dimensional molecular ?slabs? of these materials indeed exhibit greatly improves stability, this comes at the cost of inferior photovoltaic performance. Our measurements show that the different ways in which these two-dimensional materials may be arranged has a dramatic impact on the response of the lattice to stresses applied from different directions. We expect that this result will help inform future efforts to design improved materials that are both chemically and structurally robust and competitive in solar energy conversion efficiency.

Finally, we have continued working toward implementing TRSRM, and we expect to obtain our first such measurements in the coming year. In our first planned experiment, we will measure the M?ssbauer spectrum of a europium-doped glass under constant laser illumination with the goal of observing the accumulation of a transient electronic state that persists for several milliseconds. After this proof-of-principle work, we will then measure the M?ssbauer spectra of the same two-dimensional tin halide perovskites discussed above in the several nanoseconds after they absorb visible light to better understand how they generate electrical current.

Throughout this project, over a dozen faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates from across Rhode Island have participated in ultrafast laser and X-ray experiments, both at the University of Rhode Island and Argonne National Laboratory. In addition to providing invaluable training opportunities at world-class user facilities to several young scientists, this work has established a strong collaborative bond between our state and Argonne that will allow us to continue pursuing these and other projects for years to come.
